facts.text: The respondent (Bank) is a public limited company carrying on banking business at head office in Mangalore and branches elsewhere.
Bank opened one branch in Karachi on November 15, 1946.
After partition of India in 1947, currencies of India and Pakistan at par until devaluation of Indian Rupee on September 18, 1949; Pakistan did not devalue.
Exchange ratio between India and Pakistan determined on February 27, 1951: 100 Pakistani Rupees equivalent to 144 Indian Rupees.
On date of devaluation (September 18, 1949), Karachi Branch had Rs. 3,97,221/- belonging to head office.
Due to currency situation difficulties, impossible to remit amount to head office for long time.
State Bank of Pakistan permitted remittance to India on July 1, 1953; remittance on July 3, 1953.
In terms of Indian currency, amount became Rs. 5,71,038/-; appreciation/profit of Rs. 1,73,817/-; after deductions, Rs. 1,70,746/- transferred to Contingencies Reserve Account.
In return for assessment year 1954-55, Bank claimed sum as capital gain, not taxable.
Income-tax Officer by order dated February 9, 1955 rejected claim, held revenue receipt.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner affirmed ITO order.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal rejected Bank's appeal by order dated November 23, 1956.
Tribunal referred question to High Court at instance of Bank: Whether exchange difference of Rs. 1,70,746/- assessable under Indian Income-tax Act.
Mysore High Court by order dated December 11, 1961 reversed Tribunal, held not assessable.
Karachi branch not carrying on business in foreign currencies in 1949; no foreign exchange business until permitted April 3, 1951.
Even after April 3, 1951 permission and April 25, 1953 general licence, money of head office not used for business in foreign currencies.
Money lying idle in Karachi branch, not utilised in any banking operation, kept for remittance to India awaiting permission.
Sum not employed, expended or used for any banking operation or foreign exchange business at material time.
During April 3, 1951 to April 25, 1953, dealings like letters of credit, drafts in new account; old balance Rs. 3,97,221/- could not be utilised per State Bank instructions.
Amount Rs. 3,97,221/- blocked and sterilised from devaluation to remittance.
Original and supplementary statements of case dated May 15, 1957 and August 14, 1959 were agreed statements; findings not challenged before High Court.
Appellant conceded before High Court no evidence blocked balance employed for internal banking or foreign currency business.

legal_issues.text: Whether the exchange difference of Rs. 1,70,746/- is assessable under any of the provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act?

Whether the profit of the Bank on account of fluctuation of exchange arose in the course of trading operation of the Bank or whether it was incidental to any such trading operation or a capital profit.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellate Tribunal wrong in holding blocking or sterilisation of amount; balance sheets show amount utilised for internal banking operations within Pakistan.
Money was stock-in-trade of the bank; increment due to fluctuation in exchange rate must be treated as incidental to business of the Bank.

respondent_arguments.text: Appreciation did not arise in course of trading operation.

court_reasoning.text: High Court found after analysis that appreciation did not arise in course of trading operation; Karachi branch not carrying foreign currency business in 1949, money idle/blocked/sterilised, not used in banking.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Profit by exchange operations is revenue if in course of business, capital otherwise.

court_reasoning.text: Cannot permit additional evidence to controvert Tribunal findings; statements agreed, not challenged before High Court, concession no evidence of use in business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not permissible to challenge findings at this stage.

court_reasoning.text: Even assuming stock-in-trade, increment not due to trading as blocked/sterilised, changed character, not used in business; capital receipt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Money changed character when blocked; no inference of profit from business.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Imperial Tobacco Co. v. Kelly and Landes Bros. v. Simpson (dollars acquired for business, revenue character not altered); here not used in business unlike there.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Facts differ: here blocked, not part of commercial transaction.

holdings.text: Exchange difference of Rs. 1,70,746/- not assessable to income-tax; capital receipt as not arising from trading operations.
Profit on exchange fluctuation is capital if not by way of business but by blocked funds.

precedents_cited.relevance: Excess sterling from requisitioned dollars held revenue as dollars acquired for business, revenue character not altered by controls.

precedents_cited.case_name: McKinlay v. H. M. Inspector of Taxes v. H. T. Jenkins & Son Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Profit by exchange operations capital if not by way of business but by investment in foreign currencies.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Whether exchange difference assessable under any provisions

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court judgment reversing Tribunal; held exchange difference not assessable as it was capital receipt from blocked funds not used in business.
outcome.relief_granted: Bank's claim upheld; sum not taxable

key_quotes.text: If by virtue of exchange operations profits are made during the course of business and in connection with business transactions, the excess receipts on account of conversion of one currency into another would be revenue receipts. But if the profit by exchange operations comes in, not by way of business of the Bank, the profit would be capital profit.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines distinction between revenue and capital profit from exchange fluctuations.

key_quotes.text: In our opinion, the money changed its character of stock-in-trade when it was blocked and sterilised and the increment in its value owing to the exchange fluctuation must be treated as a capital receipt.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on why profit is capital despite being stock-in-trade.
